gen.conclusions: The proposed 2×2 FSP antenna array is a viable solution for small satellites, offering dual-band and dual-circularly polarized radiation in a compact form factor. It can support various communication and positioning functions while meeting the size constraints of CubeSats and picosatellites (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulation and measurement results (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: CST simulation software (p. 5); Fabricated antenna array (p. 3); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 4); CST simulation software (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Experimental design with simulation and measurement (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The design achieves dual-band operation and dual-circularly polarized radiation using meandering, folding, and shorting techniques (p. 1); The antenna array has a compact size of 50 mm × 50 mm (p. 1); The antenna array achieved good agreement between simulation and measurement results (p. 5); The proposed 2×2 FSP antenna array operates at 1.1 GHz and 2.4 GHz with dual-circularly polarized radiation (p. 1); For the upper band, the realized gain maximum was about 2 dBic at 2.3 GHz (p. 4); For the lower band, the realized gain maximum was about 0 dBic at 1.1 GHz (p. 4)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The cross-polarization level is more than 25 dB below the main broadside beam maximum for CP1 and about 18 dB below for CP2 at the upper band (p. 5); The axial ratio (AR) was determined to be less than 3 dB for the lower band and less than 1 dB for the higher frequency band over a 40° beam angular range (p. 5); The antenna array can support S-band downlinks and multiple transmitting and receiving functions for communications and positioning (p. 1); The design is more compact and uses fewer elements compared to other similar designs (p. 2); The cross-polarization level is about 15 dB below the main broadside beam maximum for CP1 and CP2 at the lower band (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna array is suitable for simultaneous L-Band and S-band operation on CubeSats, picosatellites, and other small satellite structures, offering dual circular polarization (DCP) functionality. The lower band is suitable for low data rate communications and telemetry, while the upper band is useful for downlinks and ground station communications (p. 5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to picosatellites and CubeSats and may not be directly applicable to other satellite types (p. 1); limitation_type: Fabrication tolerances | description: A slight downward shift in the operating frequencies due to practical fabrication tolerances (p. 5)
gen.metadata.keywords: folded shorted patch antenna; picosatellite; dual-circularly polarized; dual-polarized; CubeSat; dual-band; folded-shorted patch array; small satellite
gen.metadata.authors: Khalid Alrushud; Symon K. Podilchak; Yuepei Li; Khalid M. Alrushud; Bandar Alshammari
gen.metadata.title: Compact folded-shorted patch array offering dual-band operation and dual-circularly polarized radiation for picosatellites and other small satellites
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and optimize a compact 2×2 folded shorted patch (FSP) antenna array for dual-band and dual-circularly polarized radiation suitable for picosatellites and CubeSats (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve dual-band operation at 1.1 GHz and 2.4 GHz (p. 1); Reduce the physical size of the antenna to 50 mm × 50 mm (p. 1); Achieve compactness through folding, shorting, and meandering (p. 4); Evaluate the performance metrics including gain, bandwidth, and cross-polarization level (p. 4); Implement dual-circularly polarized radiation (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore the integration of the antenna array with other satellite systems (p. 1); Investigate further miniaturization techniques and performance optimization (p. 5); Investigate the performance of the antenna array in different satellite configurations and environments (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Integrate the proposed antenna design into small satellite platforms for improved communication and positioning capabilities (p. 1); Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSats and picosatellites requiring dual-band and dual-polarized operation (p. 5); Further optimize the design for specific mission requirements (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: The need for compact, dual-band, and dual-circularly polarized antennas for small satellites like CubeSats and picosatellites (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: What design techniques can be used to achieve dual-band and dual-circularly polarized radiation? (p. 1); How can the size of microstrip patch antennas be reduced for integration into small satellites? (p. 1); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna in terms of gain, bandwidth, and cross-polarization level? (p. 4); How can the antenna be designed to be compact while maintaining dual-band and dual-polarized functionality? (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Outperforms other designs in terms of compactness, dual-band operation, and dual-circularly polarized radiation (p. 2)
esp.domain_results.cross_polarization_le: 15 dB below the main broadside beam maximum for CP1 and CP2 at the lower band, more than 25 dB below for CP1 and about 18 dB below for CP2 at the upper band (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.gain: 0 dBic at 1.1 GHz (lower band), 2 dBic at 2.3 GHz (upper band) (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.radiation_pattern: Broadbeam antenna features with minor beam squint in the principal planes at about 45° (p. 4)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: −12 dB at 1.1 GHz and −15 dB at 2.4 GHz (p. 2)
esp.technical_specifications.fabrication: Copper with a thickness of 0.5 mm (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Each single-element is fed by two coaxial probes and microstrip feedlines (p. 3)

gen.conclusions: The study presented the design and testing of a dual-frequency left-hand circular polarization patch antenna array for the 3Cat-5/A satellite. The antenna met some but not all requirements, and it was used successfully in the FSSCat mission (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Measurement of S11 parameter, radiation pattern, gain, and axial ratio (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Numerical simulations (p. 2); CST Studio Suite for simulations (p. 4); Thermal vacuum chamber (TVAC) (p. 8); Theoretical analysis (p. 2); Prototyping (p. 2); Anechoic chamber (p. 9); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) for combiner measurements (p. 7); UPC Antenna Lab Anechoic Chamber for measurements (p. 5); Environmental testing (p. 1); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) (p. 9)
gen.detailed_methodology.population_cont: 3Cat-5/A satellite, part of the FSSCat mission (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Theoretical analysis, numerical simulations, prototyping, and environmental testing (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and validation of a custom antenna (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The designed antenna meets the directivity, polarization, and return loss requirements (p. 1); Combiner was designed and characterized, showing significant differences between simulations and measurements (p. 7); The S11 parameter and radiation pattern were measured before and after TVAC testing (p. 8); Single-frequency circular polarization antennas were successfully simulated and prototyped (p. 5); Dual-frequency circular polarization antenna stack was designed and simulated (p. 5); The GPS L1 band results were not compliant with all requirements, while the MWR band complied in terms of directivity and axial ratio (p. 9); The antenna was tested in a TVAC with two thermal cycles between +80°C and -20°C (p. 8); The antenna fits within the specified envelope and weight constraints (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna design includes a 3 by 2 array of six elements, each a stacked dual-band patch antenna (p. 3); The combiner showed inconsistencies due to M2.5 interface holes (p. 7); The air gap between the MWR and GPS L1 antennas reduced efficiency in the L1 band and increased axial ratio (p. 9); The dual-frequency antenna stack met the requirements for RL in the MWR band and GPS L1 (p. 7); The antenna is composed of four printed circuit boards (PCBs) (p. 3)
gen.discussion: The design and testing process identified issues with manufacturing tolerances and dielectric constant variations, which affected the antenna's performance. Despite these issues, the antenna was successfully used in the FSSCat mission for soil moisture, sea ice concentration, and sea salinity retrieval (p. 9)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Design constraints | description: The antenna must fit within a 300 mm × 200 mm × 7 mm envelope and withstand extreme temperature changes (p. 1); limitation_type: Simulation and Measurement Discrepancies | description: Significant differences between simulation and measurement results for the combiner, likely due to M2.5 interface holes (p. 7); limitation_type: Manufacturing Tolerances | description: Manufacturing tolerances and dielectric constant variations affected the antenna's performance (p. 9); limitation_type: Time Constraints | description: Due to the mission schedule, it was not feasible to perform another iteration to address the non-compliance issues (p. 9)
gen.metadata.keywords: Patch; circular polarization; Nanosatellite; thermal vacuum testing; patch antenna; antenna design; left-hand circular polarization; Antenna; CubeSat; L-band; Earth Observation; dual-frequency
gen.metadata.authors: J. Francesc Munoz-Martin; Camps, A.; Fernandez, L.; Calveras, A.; Munoz-Marti, J.F.; A. Camps; Ruiz-de-Azu, J.A.; A. Calveras; Not mentioned; J. A. Ruiz-de-Azua; L. Fernandez
gen.metadata.title: Design and validation of a dual-band circular polarization patch antenna and stripline combiner for the FSSCat mission
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design, simulate, prototype, and test a dual-frequency left-hand circular polarization patch antenna array for the 3Cat-5/A satellite (p. 8)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Design and simulate a dual-frequency circular polarization antenna stack (p. 4); Integrate and validate the Flight Model (p. 1); Perform theoretical analysis and simulations (p. 1); Design a dual-band six-patch array with a stripline combiner (p. 8); Select the best antenna type and design solution (p. 1); Simulate and prototype single-frequency circular polarization antennas (p. 4); Manufacture and test prototypes (p. 1); Characterize the combiner for the antenna array (p. 5); Perform thermal vacuum and radiofrequency characterization tests (p. 8); Define the requirements for the nadir antenna (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Explore other design solutions for even smaller and more efficient antennas (p. 1); Investigate the impact of M2.5 interface holes on combiner performance (p. 7); Conduct more extensive testing of the antenna and combiner in different environments (p. 7); Further research on improving manufacturing tolerances and dielectric constant consistency (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Future missions should remanufacture an antenna that complies with all stated requirements (p. 9); Use the designed antenna in future CubeSat missions with similar requirements (p. 1); Further optimize the combiner design to reduce discrepancies between simulations and measurements (p. 7)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Designing a nadir antenna for the FMPL-2 payload on the 3Cat-5/A 6U CubeSat, which must be directive, dual-band, left-hand circularly polarized, and fit within strict envelope and weight constraints (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a dual-band, high-directivity, left-hand circularly polarized antenna be designed for a CubeSat? (p. 1); What are the effects of environmental testing on the antenna's performance? (p. 8); How can the antenna be designed to fit within the specified dimensions and meet the required performance metrics? (p. 8); What are the optimal dimensions and configurations for achieving the desired performance? (p. 4); What are the optimal design solutions for meeting the envelope and performance requirements of the nadir antenna? (p. 1); How can a dual-frequency circular polarization patch antenna be designed for CubeSats? (p. 4)

gen.conclusions: A planar antenna based on a standing-wave fractal geometry with coaxial feeding has been designed and presented. It operates over the 2.4 GHz band with circular polarization and maximum radiation over the top face. The antenna is an excellent candidate for CubeSat systems (p. 2213)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Rohde & Schwarz FSP Spectrum Analyzer and R&S SMB 100A RF and Microwave Signal Generator for gain measurement (p. 2212); Fabricated antenna for experimental testing (p. 2214); Simulation software (p. 2214); Photolithographic process for fabrication (p. 2212); HP 8510-series Vector Network Analyzer for S11 return losses (p. 2212)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and optimization of a microstrip standing-wave fractal antenna (p. 2211)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The antenna operates in dual bands at 0.4 and 1.4 GHz (p. 2214); The antenna has a bandwidth of 10% (2.35 GHz to 2.6 GHz) (p. 2212); Measured axial ratio remains below 3 dB for the whole operating band (p. 2213); Maximum experimental gain of 5.7 dBi at 2.355 GHz (p. 2212); The antenna operates in triple bands at 0.4, 1.4, and 2 GHz (p. 2214); The antenna can be reconfigured to operate in a narrow band centered at 0.5 GHz (p. 2214); The antenna operates at 2.45 GHz with circular polarization and directional radiation (p. 2210)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: The antenna has overall dimensions of 72 × 72 mm² and a total weight of 33.7 g including the SMA-type connector (p. 2213); The antenna offers an enhanced impedance bandwidth from 300–645 MHz in single-band mode (p. 2214)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna is an excellent candidate for CubeSat applications due to its small dimensions, low weight, and good performance (p. 2213)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Fabrication | description: Small shift in operating frequency due to fabrication tolerances and addition of SMA-type connector (p. 2212); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.conclusions: The proposed antenna design, incorporating corner truncations, a slit-ring structure, and symmetrically positioned segment-circular parasitic patches, achieves wide impedance bandwidth, stable circular polarization, and a compact profile, making it well-suited for CubeSat S-band communication systems (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Parametric analysis to validate the effectiveness of each antenna design refinement (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Full-wave electromagnetic simulation software (p. 6); Smith chart analysis (p. 6); Equivalent circuit modeling (p. 6); Horn antenna (p. 12); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 17); Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) (p. 12); CST Microwave Studio Suite for simulations (p. 2); Fabricated prototype for experimental validation (p. 1); Anechoic chamber (p. 12); Simulation software (Altair FEKO) (p. 17); Not mentioned; Spiral antenna (p. 12)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and performance analysis of microstrip antennas (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: Maintained an ARBW of 1.97–2.31 GHz (15.8%) (p. 17); Achieves a stable gain of approximately 7.50 dBic at 2.025 GHz (p. 1); The antenna achieved a wide impedance bandwidth (IBW) of 1.65–2.70 GHz (50%) in stand-alone configuration (p. 14); The realized gain was approximately 7.50 dBic at 2.025 GHz (p. 7); The antenna maintained circular polarization (AR < 3 dB) over 1.97–2.32 GHz (p. 14); The fabricated prototype achieves a wide impedance bandwidth from 1.65 GHz to 2.70 GHz, fully encompassing the CubeSat uplink (2.025–2.110 GHz) and downlink (2.200–2.290 GHz) frequency ranges (p. 1); Maintains an axial ratio below 3 dB across 1.97 GHz to 2.32 GHz, ensuring efficient circular polarization (p. 1); The maximum realized gain was approximately 7.50 dBic (p. 14); Unidirectional radiation patterns with HPBW of 56°–73° and F/B ratios up to 13.53 dB (p. 17); Stable realized gain of 5.99–7.50 dBic across the operating band (p. 17); Not mentioned; Achieved an IBW of 1.65–2.70 GHz (49%) (p. 17); The sixth-generation antenna design achieved a wide IBW of 1.65–2.70 GHz and an ARBW of 1.97–2.32 GHz (p. 7)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Outperformed existing designs in terms of IBW, ARBW, gain, and compactness (p. 17); The optimal arc width (𝐿𝑃2) of the parasitic patch was 24 mm, achieving the best impedance matching and AR (p. 8); The antenna exhibited stable radiation efficiency and total efficiency, approaching 99% (p. 14); The optimal arc length (𝑊𝑃3) of the parasitic patch was 49.5 mm, achieving a wide IBW and stable AR (p. 8); The combination of compact structure, low profile, and wideband circular polarization makes the proposed antenna a promising candidate for CubeSat communication systems (p. 1); Not mentioned; The optimal truncation length (𝑊𝑃2) was 18 mm, achieving an IBW of 1.65–2.70 GHz and a maximum gain of 7.50 dBic (p. 8); The optimal slit-ring diameter (𝐷𝑇) was 2 mm, achieving a wide IBW and stable AR (p. 8); The antenna demonstrated unidirectional radiation patterns with HPBW of 56°–73° and F/B ratios up to 13.5 dB (p. 14); The optimal inter-substrate spacing was 14.3 mm, achieving the best impedance matching and AR (p. 9)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design effectively meets the stringent performance requirements of CubeSat communication systems by integrating wide IBW, strong circular polarization, stable gain, and unidirectional radiation patterns into a compact form factor (p. 17)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study focuses on a specific frequency band and design, which may limit its applicability to other frequency bands or different CubeSat configurations (p. 1); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The study is limited to the S-band and specific CubeSat applications (p. 8); limitation_type: Integration effects | description: The CubeSat-mounted configuration exhibited a narrower IBW due to chassis-induced currents and frame loading (p. 14); limitation_type: Generalizability | description: Performance may vary in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 17); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.metadata.authors: Danai Torrungrueng; W. Phakphisut; Pisit Janpangngern; S. Dentri; C. Phongcharoenpanich; P. Janpangngern; Chuwong Phongcharoenpanich; Sitthichai Dentri; Watid Phakphisut; T. Hemachai; Thanaphon Hemachai; D. Torrungrueng
gen.metadata.title: Corner-truncated patch antenna with parasitic elements and circular feed slot for S-band CubeSat applications
gen.objectives.main_objective: To propose a wideband circularly polarized unidirectional antenna for CubeSat S-band communication applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Ensure stable realized gain of 5.99–7.50 dBic across the operating band (p. 17); Incorporate corner truncations, a slit-ring structure, and symmetrically positioned segment-circular parasitic patches to enhance impedance matching and polarization performance (p. 1); Maintain stable circular polarization with an axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW) of 1.97–2.31 GHz (15.8%) (p. 17); Implement a vertical capacitive feed through a dual-stacked RT/duroid® 5880 substrate to improve current distribution and broaden the operational bandwidth (p. 1); Achieve a wide impedance bandwidth (IBW) of 1.65–2.70 GHz (49%) (p. 17); Not mentioned; Optimize the antenna design for maximum performance in the S-band (p. 5); Evaluate the impact of parasitic patches on bandwidth and circular polarization (p. 5); Evaluate the antenna's performance in a CubeSat environment (p. 10); Design a compact antenna with dimensions of 0.72𝜆0 × 0.72𝜆0 × 0.13𝜆0 at 2.150 GHz (p. 17); Optimize the antenna dimensions and configurations for maximum gain and bandwidth (p. 10); Maintain unidirectional radiation patterns with favorable HPBW and F/B ratios (p. 17)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat missions (p. 15); Explore the integration of additional design modifications to further enhance performance and broaden the operational bandwidth (p. 1); Explore the impact of different materials and configurations on antenna performance (p. 15); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 18); Not mentioned; Explore further optimizations to enhance performance metrics (p. 18); Explore the integration of the antenna with other CubeSat subsystems (p. 8); Investigate the performance of the antenna in different environmental conditions (p. 8)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Evaluate the antenna's performance in real mission conditions (p. 18); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat communication systems (p. 18); Implement the proposed antenna design in CubeSat communication systems (p. 8); Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSat communication systems (p. 15); Not mentioned; Optimize the design parameters for specific mission requirements (p. 8); Implement the antenna with low-profile and body-mounted configurations to minimize deployment risk (p. 15); Integrate the proposed antenna design into CubeSat communication systems for reliable and efficient communication (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Conventional planar microstrip patch antennas generally exhibit narrow impedance bandwidth (IBW) and axial ratio bandwidth (ARBW), due to their high quality factor (Q), which compromises their suitability for CubeSat missions that demand stable circular polarization performance across wide frequency ranges and varying incident angles (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a wideband CP unidirectional antenna be designed for CubeSat communication? (p. 17); What is the optimal design configuration for achieving high gain and wide bandwidth in S-band CubeSat antennas? (p. 5); What are the performance metrics of the proposed antenna compared to existing designs? (p. 17); How does the design of the antenna affect its performance in terms of gain, bandwidth, and circular polarization? (p. 10); How can the integration of parasitic patches enhance the bandwidth and circular polarization of microstrip antennas? (p. 5); How can the impedance bandwidth and axial ratio bandwidth of microstrip patch antennas be enhanced for CubeSat S-band communication applications? (p. 1); What are the optimal dimensions and configurations for achieving high performance in a CubeSat environment? (p. 10); Not mentioned; What design modifications can improve the circular polarization performance and gain of microstrip patch antennas for CubeSat applications? (p. 1)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: The proposed antenna outperforms other configurations in terms of IBW, ARBW, and gain (p. 7)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Corner-truncated patch antenna with parasitic elements and circular feed slot (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Single-port coaxial feed aligned along the x-axis (p. 2)

gen.conclusions: The proposed shared aperture antenna is a viable solution for CubeSats, offering high gain and circular polarization in both S-band and X-band, and saving space by replacing two separate antennas (p. 1)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Comparison of simulated and measured return loss, gain, and axial ratio (p. 8)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: Anritsu 37369A Vector Network Analyzer (VNA) for measurement (p. 7); Not mentioned; Simulation software (p. 2); Ansys HFSS 2022 for simulation (p. 5); Fabricated antenna for measurement (p. 3)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of a dual-band shared aperture antenna using finite element method (FEM) and fabrication of a prototype (pp. 5-6)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The peak gain in the X-band was 12.8 dBic (p. 1); The S-band patch had a simulated maximum RHCP gain of 7.7 dBic at 2016 MHz (p. 5); The Axial Ratio (<3 dB) bandwidth of the patch antenna in the X-band is 67 MHz (8433–8500 MHz, 0.8%) (p. 1); The X-band antenna demonstrated a bandwidth of 210 MHz (8320–8530 MHz, 2.5%) (p. 1); The X-band patch achieved a simulated S11 < −10 dB bandwidth of 210 MHz (2.5%) and a measured bandwidth of 270 MHz (p. 8); The maximum gain in the S-band reached 7.7 dBic (p. 1); Not mentioned; The S-band patch had an S11 = −10 dB bandwidth of 30 MHz (2013–2043 MHz, 1.5%) (p. 1); The X-band patch had a simulated maximum RHCP gain of 12.8 dBic at 8460 MHz (p. 6); The Axial Ratio (<3 dB) bandwidth of the slot antenna in the S-band is 7 MHz (2013–2020 MHz, 0.35%) (p. 1); The S-band patch achieved a simulated S11 < −10 dB bandwidth of 30 MHz (1.5%) and a measured bandwidth of 16 MHz (p. 6)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Not mentioned; The fabricated prototype exhibited good isolation between ports of the S-band and X-band patches (below −20 dB in the S-band and −15 dB in the X-band) (p. 8); The antenna is advantageous in terms of high gain, maintains circular polarization over a wideband, and can replace two antennas needed in CubeSats for uplink/downlink (p. 1)
gen.discussion: The proposed antenna design effectively combines the functionalities of two separate antennas into one, saving space and maintaining high performance in terms of gain and circular polarization (p. 1)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Generalizability | description: The design is specific to CubeSat applications and may not be directly applicable to other satellite types (p. 1); limitation_type: Fabrication errors | description: Differences in simulation and measurement results could be attributed to fabrication errors, including misalignment of various layers and the presence of air gaps (p. 8); limitation_type: Not mentioned | description: Not mentioned

gen.metadata.title: A Multi-Band Circularly Polarized-Shared Aperture Antenna for Space Applications at S and X Bands
gen.objectives.main_objective: To design and analyze a compact multiband antenna that shares the aperture of an S-band slot antenna to accommodate an X-band patch antenna for CubeSat applications (p. 1)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve high gain and maintain circular polarization over a wideband (p. 1); Not mentioned; Replace two separate antennas with a single shared aperture antenna to save space (p. 1); Achieve high gain and compact size (p. 9); Ensure good isolation between S-band and X-band patches (p. 9)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Investigate the performance of the antenna in different CubeSat configurations and environments (p. 1); Investigate the performance of the antenna in real CubeSat missions (p. 9)

gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a shared aperture antenna be designed to operate in both S-band and X-band for CubeSat applications? esp.domain_methodology.simulation_method: Finite element method (FEM) using Ansys HFSS 2022 (p. 5)
esp.domain_results.comparison_with_other: Achieved similar or better performances while keeping the antenna size compact compared to other recent works (p. 9)
esp.domain_results.return_loss: S-band: −30 dB (simulated), −16 dB (measured), X-band: −210 dB (simulated), −270 dB (measured) (p. 6, p. 8)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Shared aperture antenna with S-band and X-band patches (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Two separate 50Ω coaxial probes for S-band and X-band patches (p. 3)
esp.technical_specifications.superstrate: Dielectric layer-3 acts as a partial reflective surface (PRS) (p. 3)

gen.conclusions: The designed antennas can be installed on the surface of a 1U CubeSat with other satellite components like a payload, solar panel, and so forth easily. They can be used not only for satellite-ground station communication but also for inter satellite communication with a small amount of polarization mismatch according to the linear polarized case (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_analysis: Simulation and measurement of return loss, gain, and radiation patterns (p. 4)
gen.detailed_methodology.data_collection: PCB prototyping machine (p. 5); Measurement equipment (p. 4); Simulation software (p. 4); Full-wave electromagnetic simulator (p. 5); Anechoic chamber for measurements (p. 5)
gen.detailed_methodology.research_approa: Design and simulation of two different antenna structures (pp. 1-4)
gen.detailed_methodology.study_type: Design and manufacturing of two different antenna prototypes (p. 5)
gen.detailed_results.main_findings: The measured impedance bandwidth of the second design is about 1.68% where the center frequency is about 2.443 GHz (p. 5); Measured percentage impedance bandwidths were 2% and 1.68%, respectively (p. 1); Maximum gain of about 5 dBic around the target frequency (p. 1); The bandwidth of the prototyped antenna (Design 1) has been measured to be about 2% where the center frequency is about 2.44 GHz (p. 5); The obtained maximum gain is about 5.02 dBic (p. 5); The obtained maximum gain is 5.8 dBic (p. 5); Two designs were implemented on two different substrates, occupying footprints of 38 mm × 38 mm and 30 mm × 30 mm (p. 1)
gen.detailed_results.secondary_findings: Radiation efficiency of the antenna is in the range of 72% and 80% through the impedance bandwidth for Design 2 (p. 5); The antenna is low-profile, circularly polarized, and wide-band (p. 1); Radiation efficiency of the antenna is in the range of 79% and 84% through the impedance bandwidth for Design 1 (p. 5)
gen.discussion: The proposed antennas have been implemented on relatively high permittivity substrates using conventional printed circuit manufacturing technology enabling cost effective and reliable component realization. Simulations and optimizations have been realized on a commercially available full-wave electromagnetic simulator. Measurement and simulation results show a good agreement (p. 5)
gen.limitations: limitation_type: Bandwidth | description: Narrower bandwidth due to reactive loadings from tapering the slots and using a relatively thick substrate (p. 4); limitation_type: Impedance Bandwidth | description: The impedance bandwidth is limited to 2% and 1.68% for the two designs, respectively (p. 5)
gen.metadata.keywords: circularly polarized antenna; antennas; nanosatellite; satellite antennas; space vehicle antennas; electrically small antennas; slot antennas; printed antenna; CubeSat; microstrip antenna
gen.metadata.title: Electrically Small Printed Antenna for Applications on Cubesat and Nano-Satellite Platforms
gen.objectives.main_objective: To present a circularly polarized electrically small antenna for CubeSats and nanosatellite platforms (p. 5)
gen.objectives.specific_objectives: Achieve a low-profile, wide-band antenna (p. 1); Prevent mismatching due to using high dielectrics loading (p. 5); Achieve a good agreement between simulation and measurement results (p. 5); Implement antennas on relatively high permittivity substrates using conventional printed circuit manufacturing technology (p. 5); Fit the antenna within the limited physical volume of CubeSats (p. 1); Ensure the antenna is circularly polarized (p. 1)
gen.recommendations.for_future_research: Not mentioned; Further optimization of the antenna design for improved bandwidth and efficiency (p. 4)
gen.recommendations.for_practice: Three or four antenna elements can constitute an array on one face of a CubeSat for a beam steering by using appropriate phase differences between them to use in a satellite network (p. 5); Use the proposed antenna design for CubeSat and nanosatellite communication systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.problem_statement: Nanosatellite and CubeSats have very limited volume and surfaces bringing a physical size constraint on the components and antennas which should also be as functional as their counterparts used in similar terrestrial systems (p. 1)
gen.research_problem.research_questions: How can a compact, circularly polarized antenna be designed for CubeSat and nanosatellite platforms? (p. 1); How can a circularly polarized electrically small antenna be designed for CubeSats and nanosatellite platforms? (p. 5)
esp.domain_methodology.measurement_condi: 100 mm × 100 mm ground plane to model one face surface of a 1U CubeSat (p. 5)
esp.technical_specifications.antenna_typ: Cavity-backed antenna with tapered crossed-slot aperture (p. 1)
esp.technical_specifications.feeding_ele: Combination of probe and CPW-like strip with tapered slots (p. 5)
l1 = 29 mm, l2 = 30.3 mm, wcs = 1.3 mm, lcs = 9.67 mm, wsl = 2.4 mm, lsl = 10.72 mm (Design 1) (p. 4)
